item.title: On Trip to Turkey, Pope Francis Calls for Dialogue in Battling ISIS
item.description: Pope Francis argued that force alone would not defeat extremists, and he urged that people of all faiths be treated equally before the law.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the new presidential palace in Ankara during a three-day visit to Turkey.

item.title: Taliban Press Attacks Against Afghan Targets
item.description: Taliban insurgents continued a sudden pattern of intense assaults, another sign that the traditional fighting season has been prolonged.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: An Afghan security official inspecting the site of a bomb attack in the northern Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif on Friday.

item.title: Pope, in Turkey, Calls for Muslim Opposition to Islamic State
item.description: Pope Francis condemned the Islamic State assault on Christians and other religions minorities in Iraq and Syria, as he arrived in Turkey for a three-day visit.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the new presidential palace in Ankara during a three-day visit to Turkey.

item.title: Explosions Hit Worshippers in Northern Nigeria
item.description: Gunmen exploded bombs and opened fire on worshippers gathered at the central mosque of Kano, northern Nigeria’s biggest city.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: French Lawmakers Debate Recognizing a Palestinian State
item.description: A nonbinding motion on the matter is expected to pass comfortably when it is put to a vote in the lower house of Parliament on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: P. D. James, Novelist Known as ‘Queen of Crime,’ Dies at 94
item.description: A consummate stylist, the British author and baroness accumulated numerous awards for the 18 crime novels produced during her 49-year writing career.
item.dc:creator: By MARILYN STASIO
item.media:description: P.D. James, in 2010. She was called the “Queen of Crime,” for her complex mysteries.

item.title: Japanese Newspaper Prints Apology for Using the Term ‘Sex Slaves’
item.description: The conservative Yomiuri Shimbun said it was “inappropriate” to suggest that those known euphemistically as “comfort women” had been recruited against their will.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: India’s Economic Growth Slows to 5.3%
item.description: Manufacturing and agricultural output dragged on growth in the last quarter, raising pressure on Prime Minister Narendra Modi to expand his economic revival efforts.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: David Cameron Toughens Stance on Immigration in Britain
item.description: The prime minister said he would make Britain a less attractive place for European migrants to seek employment, and would try to exclude them for four years from social and welfare benefits.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain hopes to curb immigration in his country, but he has not proposed imposing quotas.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Ann E. Carlson and Alex Wang on the U.S.-China Climate Accord
item.description: Alex Wang and Ann E. Carlson, law professors at the University of California, Los Angeles, who study environmental policy and regulations in the United States and China, responded to questions about the United States-China agreement on cutting greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A man wears a mask to protect against polluted air outside the Forbidden City in Beijing.

item.title: Australia Promises Scrutiny After Death of Cricket Star Phillip Hughes
item.description: However, officials displayed little readiness to disrupt what one administrator called the game’s “finely tuned balance between bat and ball.”
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Phillip Hughes, billed as a rising international star among Australian batters, was hit in the head by a ball during a domestic game in Sydney.

item.title: European Union Gives Belgium, France and Italy Time to Comply on Budget Rules
item.description: The decision is a sign that the European Commission, the bloc’s executive arm, under Jean-Claude Juncker will be sensitive to calls to ease up on austerity.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Drafts Its First Domestic Violence Law, but Rights Advocates Say It Falls Short
item.description: Lawyers and women’s advocates welcomed the proposed national law, but said there were loopholes that would allow police officers to shirk taking action on those calls at their discretion.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Families visiting Tiananmen Square in Beijing. The proposed Anti-Domestic Violence Law aims “to preserve equal, harmonious and civilized family relationships."

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dai Xiang’s Modern Take on a Classic Chinese Painting
item.description: The artist borrows the visual and conceptual framework of “Along the River During the Qingming Festival,” a 12-century painting, to produce a patchwork of vignettes of everyday Chinese society.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A scene showing fishermen demanding payment before handing over the bodies of students who died while trying to save drowning children.

item.title: Stasi Art Seizure Leads to Court Case Involving New Yorkers
item.description: Between 1973 and 1989, the East German police seized more than 200,000 objects in hundreds of raids, according to experts and archives, and some are reclaiming the art.
item.dc:creator: By TOM MASHBERG
item.media:description: “Still Life With Chestnuts” from 1705, by Adriaen Coorte, was one of the most valuable items seized from Helmuth Meissner's collection in 1982, his son says.

item.title: World Briefing: Sudan: Tribal Clashes Inflict Heavy Toll
item.description: At least 133 people have been killed and more than 100 wounded in clashes between two groups belonging to an Arab tribe in West Kordofan State, a tribal leader said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: European Commission’s President Survives No-Confidence Vote
item.description: The European Commission’s new president, Jean-Claude Juncker, comfortably survived a no-confidence vote on Thursday that was prompted by news that Luxembourg had lured multinational businesses with super-low tax rates during his period as its prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: 13 Inmates Die During Prison Disturbance, Government Says
item.description: At least 13 prisoners died of drug overdoses after inmates stormed a prison infirmary during protests organized to demand better living conditions, the government said Thursday, but activists questioned the official version and said the death toll could be far higher.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Despite Aid Push, Ebola Is Raging in Sierra Leone
item.description: After calling for an ambulance more than 35 times, a family in Sierra Leone, where Ebola has hit harder than in neighboring countries, waited for three days for help to arrive.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Freetown’s outskirts, burly youth are setting up roadblocks. The police are nowhere to be found. The young men barricade the road brandishing digital thermometers.

item.title: Chinese Dissident’s Trial to Begin
item.description: Yang Maodong and another activist were set to go on trial in China on Friday, the latest adversaries of the Communist Party’s censorship likely to be convicted and imprisoned for years.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
